pullRequest.body:
Use `haveI` to drop unneeded `Nonempty`/`Inhabited` assumptions.

---

nodes.body:
Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8072570069/job/22054587529)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8072570069/job/22054588049)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8072570069/job/22054588458)
I think this would be cleaner with a `haveI` (the underlying term should be the same, `I` stands for inlined)
Same as above, I think it would be cleaner with some `haveI`.

Why not make `f` implicit here? Apparently it doesn't change anything in practice, I don't really understand why though.

Also, what do you think about defining instead `Filter.lim'`, which takes a `NeBot f` instance instead of `Nonempty α` ?
I can add a reducible `def Filter.NeBot.lim` that takes `NeBot f` as an explicit argument. If we use an instance-implicit argument, then it doesn't help here.

Ah sure I'm stupid. Then what we would want is probably my `lim'` with the instance and still another `Cauchy.lim` abbreviation on top of it. So since we would need the extra abbreviation in any case I'd say sticking with the current setup is fine.
I loogled for `lim` and `Cauchy`. They're used together twice. So, I just added `haveI`s instead of an abbreviation.
Inside the proof, we can just use `have`. It makes sense using `haveI` for the type though, since you want it to be inlined.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Cauchy): drop `Nonempty`/`Inhabited` assumptions
